content.description: Three different kid warmup routes can be used as an easy descent from the Seedhouse Camp Boulder.
content.protection: Some kids may feel the need of a backup rope thrown over the boulder. Some use of smearing can be tough for those new to the technique.

content.description: Southside Crimpers head up a steep sitdown start of sequency movements. I used a good sidecling with my left hand, a high left foot, a small, right hand crimp, then a long deadpoint to a good, small edge located just below a difficult mantle. The mantle was my crux. A sidepull is far left if you can work it that way. Use a pad to cover an exposed, flat boulder below the topout.
content.protection: Use a pad to cover an exposed flat boulder below the topout.

content.description: Seedhouse Boulder's friction slab offers several different route options, but the most obvious and easier line heads up the center of the face. Start on positive feet and follow the left-facing edges to an upper friction slab that requires good smears.

Seedhouse Boulder offers a sitdown start on a flake located on the northwest side of the rock. Start on the lower right side of the flake and head up left on layback edges using small feet. Holds improve qickly and then the throw. Depending on how tall you can make yourself, start the throw from the last two positive, flake jugs. High feet allow for a great throw to a positive, open-pinch slopper. Move your right foot up and head to the top on positive friction.
content.protection: Great landing, but a bouldering pad couldn't hurt.
